name: HD 221416
scenarioDescription:
The HD 221416 Exoplanetary System

HD 221416 is a star with 1.21 times the mass of the Sun, and 2.94 times its radius. It is located 310.11 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 4.9 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

HD 221416 is known to have 1 exoplanets in orbit around it.

HD 221416 b

HD 221416 b was discovered by the Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite (TESS) observatory using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.12 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 14.28 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, HD 221416.

Its eccentricity, the extent to which the shape of the exoplanet's orbit departs from a perfect circle (Earth's is 0.0167, which is why the shape of Earth's orbit is circular rather than oval in appearance), is 0.115, which means that when HD 221416 b is at is at its closest point to its host star, 0.11 astronomical units separates the two, and when it is at its farthest point, this number is 0.14. In the case of Earth, these numbers are 0.9832899 and 1.0167103 respectively.

The mass of HD 221416 b is 60.38 times the mass of Earth. The radius of HD 221416 b is 9.17 that of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, HD 221416 b is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system HD 221416, which contains 1 planets and was discovered by Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite (TESS).
